items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide on Sunday evening. High water at Ilfracombe is at 7.45pm, times of high water will vary along the coast.
Force 4 southerly winds and offshore wave heights of 0.9m are forecast. Expect tides to be around 70mm higher than predicted.
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.
Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.
Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level  is 5.15 mAOD, this is 0.07 metres above astronomical tide level.

items.description: West Bay Harbour
items.message:
Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to forecast conditions with the highest spring tides of 2022.
Areas most at risk include West Bay Harbour and the tidal stretch of the River Brit.
No property flooding is expected.
Flooding is possible at West Bay Harbour and the tidal stretch of the River Brit from 06:45 PM on 11/09/2022.
The detailed tidal information for those who use it is for a peak level at West Bay Harbour of 2.53 mAODN at 07:30 PM on 11/09/2022, with south-easterly force 4 winds. (mAODN is height above average sea level - for more info refer to local tide tables.) No rainfall is forecast.
The tide at 07:30 PM on 12/09/2022 is also forecast to be a Flood Alert,Â we will send an update once this current tide has passed.
Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences.
We will continue to monitor the forecast.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 01:00 PM on 12/09/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message: Flood Alert updated due to continued high spring tides.  First forecast high water is 21:00 on 11/09/22 with a level of 7.63 mAOD and a Force 4 South Easterly wind. Second forecast high water is 09:30 on 12/09/22 with a level of 7.35 mAOD and a Force 3 South Easterly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth. mAOD is height above average sea level, for more detail refer to local tide tables. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible for one to two hours either side of the high tide.  We expect flooding to affect the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton. The high spring tides will continue until Monday evening 12/09/22 so this alert will remain in place until then. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and be careful along promenades, coastal footpaths and roads. This message will be updated by 11:00 on Monday, 12/09/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wye Estuary in Gloucestershire
items.message:
A flood alert remains in force as a result of high spring tides. Tides will next be high between 20:00 and 22:00 this evening, Sunday 11/09/22. Flooding to properties, roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide.  Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Wye Estuary from Redbrook to Chepstow. 
Predicted peaks:- Avonmouth Portbury 7.6m to 7.9m at 21:00 Sunday evening 11/09/22 and 7.4m to 7.6m at 09:30 Monday morning 12/09/22, Newport 7.3m to 7.6m at 21:00 Sunday evening 11/09/22 and 7.0m to 7.2m at 09:15 Monday morning 12/09/22. 
The current series of high tides will continue for the next 2 days, but will be starting to reduce after this evenings high tide.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please be careful along promenades, coastal footpaths and roads.
Please call 999 if in immediate danger.  
This message will be updated by 01:00 on Monday 12/09/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Mersey Estuary at Warrington
items.message: River levels are expected to be higher than usual at Fiddlers Ferry, Eastford Road, and Arpley Bridge as a result of a high tide tomorrow morning (12/09/22). Consequently, flooding of low lying land, roads and farmland is expected between 2:00 am and 3:00am on 12/09/22 in the following places: Fiddlers Ferry, between 2:00 AM and 2:30AM , Eastford Road, between 2:15 AM and 2:45 am, Arpley Bridge, between 2:30AM and 3:00  am. It is possible that river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge. Flood alerts may also be required for subsequent high tides. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring weather forecasts and river levels and will issue flood warnings if necessary. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated tomorrow.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 23:59 on Sunday 11/09/2022.

Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected 1 hour before and 1 hour after this time.

No flooding of properties is expected.

Avoid footpaths along the coastline and estuary. Take care planning driving routes to coastal roads, which may be flooded.

Further flood alerts may be issued during this high spring tide phase, which lasts until Tuesday 13/09/2022.

This message will be updated by 10:00 on Monday 12/09/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast at North Morecambe Bay
items.message: As a result of high spring tides, tides will be high overnight on 11/09/2022. The tides will peak around 01:00 on 12/09/2022 but will be high for a couple of hours either side. Areas most at risk include Coast at North Morecambe Bay from Roosebeck to Carnforth including low lying areas around Ulverston, Greenodd, Haverthwaite, Flookburgh, Grange-over-Sands, Levens, Milnthorpe, Sandside, Arnside and Silverdale. No property flooding is expected. We are closing locks and flood gates in the area. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads. This message will be updated by Monday afternoon, 12/09/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from Heysham to Cockerham
items.message:

We do not anticipate that further flood alerts will be required during this high spring tide phase.

This message will be updated by 10:00 on Monday 12/09/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lune estuary south west of Lancaster
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 23:59 on Sunday 11/09/2022.

Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected between 1 hour before and 1 hour after this time.

No flooding of properties is expected.

To reduce the risk of flooding we are closing flood gates on Lancaster Quay.

Avoid footpaths along the coastline and estuary. Take care planning driving routes to coastal roads, which may be flooded.

We do not anticipate that further flood alerts will be required during this high spring tide phase.

This message will be updated by 10:00 on Monday 12/09/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from Silloth to St Bees
items.message:
As a result of high spring tides and strong winds, tides will be at their highest overnight at 01:30 AM on 12/09/2022.
Areas most at risk include Low lying areas along the coast from Silloth to St Bees Head including Allonby, Maryport, Flimby, Workington, Parton and Whitehaven.
No property flooding is expected.
We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 3 days and as a result we may issue further alerts/warnings.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads.
This message will be updated Monday afternoon on 12/09/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: The flood alert for the Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall has been issued for tomorrow mornings tide, Monday 12th September 2022, between 6.30am and 9.30am.  A high spring tide and onshore winds are likely to cause overtopping waves and spray along the coast. The particular area at risk is Southfield farm. Please be careful along beaches, coastal and estuary footpaths and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous. We will continue to monitor the forecast closely. This message will be updated in the morning, Monday 12th September, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: The flood alert for the North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea has been issued for tomorrow morning's tide, Monday 12th September 2022, between 6.30am and 9.30am.  A high spring tide and onshore winds are likely to cause overtopping waves and spray along the coast. The particular area at risk is Kilnsea. Please be careful along beaches, coastal and estuary footpaths and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous. We will continue to monitor the forecast closely. This message will be updated on Monday morning 12th September, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Calder catchment

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Calder, Walsden Water, Hebden Water

items.message:
This flood alert has been issued based on the forecast for overnight rain. Rain is expected from Sunday evening and will continue through the night and into Monday morning. 

We are expecting rivers to respond from the early hours of Monday, with levels at Walsden and Todmorden currently forecast to peak around breakfast time. 

There is some uncertainty in the forecast to the amount of rain we are expecting.

There is a risk to low lying land and a potential for surface water.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message: River levels for today's high tides are expected to be lower than what was observed early this morning. This Flood Alert may be reissued tomorrow for high tides from the early hours of Tuesday morning onwards.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: Levels are now well below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Wye Estuary at Brockweir
items.message:
A flood warning has been issued as a result of high spring tides. Tides will next be high between 20:00 and 22:00 this evening, Sunday 11/09/22. Flooding to properties, roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide.  
The current series of high tides will continue for the next 2 days, but will be starting to reduce after this evenings high tide. High tides may impact properties and roads in and around Brockweir on the Wye Estuary.
Predicted peaks:- Avonmouth Portbury 7.6m to 7.9m at 21:00 Sunday evening 11/09/22 and 7.4m to 7.6m at 09:30 Monday morning 12/09/22. Newport 7.3m to 7.6m at 21:00 Sunday evening 11/09/22 and 7.0m to 7.2m at 09:15 Monday morning 12/09/22.   

We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please be careful along promenades, coastal footpaths and roads. Please call 999 if in immediate danger.
This message will be updated  by 01:00 on 12/09/22, or as the situation changes.
